title: single use items not just
story: All single use items - not just plastic - could face charges in ‘throwaway culture’ clampdownMinisters look to ramp up green powers ahead of the UN COP climate change conference in GlasgowAll single-use items could face new charges Image: Lancs LiveByRachel Wearmouth:,  Oct | commentsExtra charges on all single-use items - not just plastic - will be part of a Government crackdown on throwaway culture. The move could mean the p charge on plastic carriers could be replicated for many other things, such as coffee stirrers and straws. Ministers are set to announce the new green powers in the Commons on Wednesday.It comes as Boris Johnson prepares to host the UN COP climate change summit in Glasgow later this month.It is hoped the charges will nudge consumers to use more sustainable items, after the plastic carrier bag charge cut sales in main supermarkets by %. The bill already contained laws to make it easier for ministers to introduce charges on single-use plastics, but the amendments push to introduce charges on all single-use products. “This change to the Environment Bill will mean we can put an end to ‘here-today gone-tomorrow’ throwaway culture and move towards sustainable alternatives,” a Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs source has said. The campaign has been led by Labour ’s Shadow Environment Minister Baroness Jones of Whitchurch, who has been pushing for the change in the Government’s flagship Environment Bill.“This concession is an important first step in reducing our reliance on single-use items, which have an environmental cost whether they are made out of plastic or other materials such as wood, she told The i paper. “While we have welcomed the Government’s incremental bans on certain plastic items, it is clear that ministers need a wider range of tools to tackle the throw-away culture that creates unnecessary waste and litter.” Ruth Chambers of the Greener UK coalition said: “This is very welcome news. “A plastics only measure would have simply moved producers and consumers to single use alternatives that are often unrecyclable. “It is right that the Environment Bill should tackle our throwaway culture head on.” The levy on plastic carrier bags increased to p from p on May  and now applies to every retailer, from giant supermarket chains to corner shops, small clothes boutiques, butchers, greengrocers and airport duty-free stores Before this, the p levy only applied only to shops with more than  staff but it has resulted in the average person in England buying just four bags a year from the big store chains – a massive reduction from  bags each in . While it is thought the new scheme for all single-use items could be similar, the full details are not yet known. story: Social media bosses could face criminal sanctions as Boris Johnson signals climbdownThe Prime Minister suggested he could change course on his watered-down online safety law to make tech firm directors criminally liable for extremist content on their sBoris Johnson signalled a climbdown on sanctions for online extremism Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Social media bosses could be made criminally liable for extremist content on their s, as Boris Johnson signalled he would backtrack on his watered-down online safety law.Former Digital minister Oliver Dowden had previously resisted including criminal sanctions in the forthcoming bill, saying tech firms were “much more motivated by financial consequences than they are by the criminal liability of inidual people.”But Keir Starmer raised the idea of criminal liability, backed by campaign groups including the NSPCC, at Prime Minister’s questions. “Tough sanctions are clearly needed,” the Labour leader said.“Yet under the governmentaposs current proposals, directors of companies failing to crack down on extremism would still not face criminal sanctions, why is that ”Mr Starmer told MPs extremist material was readily available online - referring to the Mirror’s revelation that  hours’ worth of videos of hate preacher Anjem Choudary found in seconds on Google, just days after the murder of Tory MP Sir David Amess. The Labour leader went on: “The government could stop this by making it clear that directors of companies are criminally liable for material on their sites. “We donapost need to delay, so in the collaborative spirit we saw on Monday, will the PM commit to taking this away, looking at it again and working with all of us to strengthen his proposed legislation.” The Prime Minister committed to looking at “anything to strengthen” the long-awaited bill.  Asked to confirm whether the PM agreed with Mr Starmer on the need for criminal sanctions, the Prime Minister’s Deputy Spokesman said: “You have the PMaposs words. “We are obviously very much alive to this issue which is why we wanted to create a legal duty of care through the online safety bill and we will continue to listen and work with the companies involved and any recommendations will be considered in the usual way. Shadow Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Jo Stevens said: After months of campaigning by Labour it was heartening to hear that Boris Johnson has relented and will introduce criminal sanctions for senior tech executives who break the rules, as part of the long awaited Online Safety Bill. We will be ensuring these are not just warm words, but that this law is toughened up. to do whataposs needed to make our online spaces safe. We must stop online spaces from being safe spaces for terrorists. title: the online world become toxic
story: The online world has become toxic for too many of us - we need changeAfter a three year delay, the Conservatives’ promised draft Bill has finally been published but it’s weak, ineffective and won’t do the job we need it to do, writes Labours Jo Stevens MP, Shadow Digital SecretaryThe online world has become toxicImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByJo Stevens, Shadow Digital Secretary:,  Oct | commentsWe all know that the online world has become toxic for too many of us. From abusive behaviour that causes real damage and shuts down debate to the extremism that spreads terrying ideas and incites people to commit murder. After a three year delay, the Conservatives’ promised draft Bill has finally been published but it’s weak, ineffective and won’t do the job we need it to do.As the testimony from Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen has shown, making money is all these companies care about.Facebook knew its app was damaging children’s mental health but chose to do nothing. Imaginea drugs company was selling something that made kids sick or a toy firm was selling dangerous a product, they would rightly suffer severe consequences.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  The first change we need in the Bill is to include criminal sanctions against the senior executives of the big companies for repeated breaches of the new law. We need a strong incentive to change the culture of those companies and how they operate. Without personal liability, nothing will change. And we know this works, we have it in health and safety law and in banking. Itaposs not good enough that the Conservatives left this out of their draft Bill.And it should not have taken Keir Starmer to push on this at PMQs for Boris Johnson to perform a U-turn.Another big omission from the Bill is a tough rule around legal but harmful content like racist abuse suffered by our footballers, misogyny suffered by just about any woman in public le and other abuse that makes le a misery but doesn’t hit a criminal threshold.  We need a tough duty of care on the companies which covers all that abuse because it can’t be left up to social media companies to self police it. They have already shown they can’t, or won’t do it voluntarily.After England lost the Euros final, Instagram said that monkey emojis used to attack Saka and other black players did not breach its rules. So self regulation by these companies has had its day. Finally there is a big worry that this Bill has a two tier approach to digital s putting tougher rules in place for the big “category ” sites like Facebook and Twitter but putting less stringent rules in place for the smaller sites.But as Hope Not Hate and the Anti Semitism Policy Trust and others have warned, it’s often the smaller s that host the most terrying and dangerous content with Twitter and Facebook acting as a shop window for the more extreme material. Labour believes this needs to be addressed because excluding these sites from stronger rules is playing into the hands of those who want to spread this dangerous extremism.On Wednesday, under pressure from Keir Starmer, the Prime Minister promised to bring in criminal sanctions and to bring forward the second reading of the Bill before Christmas. We will be holding him to these promises. We need our laws in place as soon as possible and for them to be effective to make all our online lives safer. Because we know from bitter experience that harms against people online can quickly move offline. title: uk new zealand strike trade
story: UK and New Zealand strike trade deal which will make sauvignon blanc p cheaperBoris Johnson and Kiwi counterpart Jacinda Ardern sealed an agreement to boost trade between the two countriesThe Prime Minister is celebrating after striking a post-Brexit trade deal with New Zealand Image: Getty ImagesByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Britain and New Zealand tonight struck a trade deal which Boris Johnson claimed would slash red tape for businesses and end tarfs.The pact with the Kiwis was sealed in a video call between the Prime Minister and his counterpart Jacinda Ardern, after  months of talks. The Department for International Trade said the “groundbreaking” agreement will cut the price of New Zealand sauvignon blanc wine by p - which is its current tarf - and make Manuka honey and kiwi fruits cheaper. It will also create more chances for Britons to live and work in New Zealand - and “deeper cooperation on digital trade and climate change”, the ministry said. Get a daily morning politics briefing straight to your inbox.for the free Mirror Politics newsletter UK-New Zealand trade was worth £.billion last year and is expected to grow under the deal. However, it was unclear what the agreement means for imports of New Zealand lamb. Welsh farmers fear cheap lamb from Down Under on British supermarket shelves could hammer the UK’s sheep farming industry. Mr Johnson said: “This is a great trade deal for the United Kingdom, cementing our long friendship with New Zealand and furthering our ties with the Indo-Pacic.  “It will benefit businesses and consumers across the country, cutting costs for exporters and opening up access for our workers.” Ms Ardern said: The United Kingdom and New Zealand are great friends and close partners the historical connections that bind us run deep. “This world-leading free trade agreement lays the foundations for even stronger connections as both countries embark on a new phase in our relationship. “It is good for our economies, our businesses and our people. British business leaders hailed the agreement.  Federation of Small Businesses chairman Mike Cherry said: “New Zealand has long been a priority market for UK’s small exporters – more than a quarter of which already sell there – and we welcome efforts to build on existing trade ties that go back many decades.” Food and Drink Federation international trade chief Dominic Goudie said: “Our manufacturers will benefit from an ambitious trade deal with New Zealand that removes a range of tarfs that currently constrain exports. “Signicant growth opportunities exist as UK production becomes more competitive in the New Zealand market.” But Shadow International Trade Secretary Emily Thornberry claimed the deal would mean job losses for Britain’s farming communities, produce no extra growth and “generate just £million in additional exports for UK firms compared to pre-pandemic levels”.  She said: “As our economy recovers from the pandemic, we need trade deals that will boost jobs and growth, open up big new markets for UK exporters, and support our objectives to buy, make and sell more in Britain. “This trade deal with New Zealand fails on every count. “It is a deal whose only major winners are the mega-corporations who run New Zealand’s meat and dairy farms - all at the expense of British farmers who are already struggling to compete. “But for British jobs, growth and exports, this deal is yet another massive failure.” National Farmers’ Union President Minette Batters said the deal meant Britain “will be opening our doors to signicant extra volumes of imported food - whether or not produced to our own high standards - while securing almost nothing infor UK farmers”.  The pact involves “signicant upsides for farmers on the other side of the world who can now access our hugely valuable market but contains little discernible benefit for UK producers, either at home or overseas”, she warned. Ms Batters feared it could “damage the viability of many British farms in the years ahead, to the detriment of the public, who want more British food on their shelves, and to the detriment of our rural communities and cherished farmed landscapes”. She added: “The Government is now asking British farmers to go toe-to-toe with some of the most export-orientated farmers in the world, without the serious, long-term and properly funded investment in UK agriculture that can enable us to do so.”Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON International TradeFederation of Small BusinessesBoris JohnsonRed tapePoliticsAnimalsNew ZealandBrexitAfter BrexitEmily Thornberry" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news another-lockdown-winter-plan-explained-"Lockdown: ‘I would rule that out’ says Kwasi KwartengByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Itaposs been four months since England’s last national lockdown officially ended and le finally started going back to normal for millions of people across the country.But with cases of Covid- rising signicantly over the last few weeks and winter on the way, there are fears that another shutdown could be on the way.In recent figures, it was revealed coronavirus infections are rising in  areas in the UK and daily cases have topped the , mark for much of the last week. With the addition of delays in the booster jab rollout, as well as immunity waning and a new Delta iant in the UK, it is feared restrictions may have to .But in the question is, what kind and when  What is the government’s plan to tackling Covid this winter   The government previously announced a Plan A and Plan B to tackle the spread of Covid- this winter, though the latter has yet to kick in. Plan A includes booster jabs for the over-s and other vulnerable groups, offering a first dose to  to -year-olds and advice to wear masks in enclosed spaces. Much of this is underway already but nevertheless infections are still rising at an alarming rate Plan A includes no additional restrictions introduced over winter, meaning there is no limit to how many people you can meet, and pubs and restaurants wonapost be closed. The government are hoping to avoid addition restricting by relying on the Covid booster jabs programme, which is being offered to around  million people, including the over s, younger adults with health conditions, and frontline health and social care workers. The NHS Test and Trace will continue, as well as the offer of free PCR test for those who have symptoms of Covid-. The government is also encouraging those who are being offered the flu jab to take it up. Brits are also being reminded to wear face coverings in crowded places, and let fresh in when meeting indoors, although this is not mandatory. According to government documents, in the event that “Plan A is not sufficient in keeping the virus at manageable levels”, Plan B will go ahead. However they have yet to make clear what the tipping point for this will be. What is Plan B   Plan B would involve theof mandatory masks, including in schools. According to the governmentaposs Autumn and Winter Plan document: If Plan B is implemented, the Government will bring back the legal requirement to wear face coverings in some settings. The precise settings will be decided at the time. In addition, schools will be handed a contingency framework for what to dovirus cases surge. This could involve theof bubbles. Mandatory vaccine passports for venues could be activated at a weekaposs notice. Under Plan B, the government would also consider asking people to work from homethey can, for a limited period”. The document states: The Government recognises this causes more disruption and has greater immediate costs to the economy and some businesses than the other Plan B interventions, so a final decision would be made based on the data at the time. Clear guidance and communications will be issued to the public and businesses, setting out the steps they should take to manage the increased risks of the virus, although itaposs not yet clear what this would involve.To find out more about Plan B, you can read our separate guide here.Will there be another lockdown this winter   Do you think Plan A will work  Let us know in the comments below. The government has said itaposs very unlikely that the nation will go into lockdown. This is due to the success of the Covid vaccination programme, which will hopefully reduce transmission and relieve pressure on the NHS. The government is hoping that by outlining Plan A and Plan B, there wonapost be a need for a national lockdown this winter. However, although ministers expect Plan B measures to be sufficient to avoid a signicant increase in infections, there is no guarantee another lockdown is off the table. Dr Quinton Fivelman, Chief Scientic Officer at London Medical Laboratory, warned thatnumbers continue to increase the government would be forced to introduce a non-existent Plan C. However, the government has insisted lockdown would be a last resort. Speaking about the Covid lockdown plan on BBC Breakfast, Mr Javid said: No one wants to see another lockdown, I certainly don’t. I don’t think we are going to need to see another lockdown. I think the vaccines are working. “But I think it would be irresponsible for any health minister in the world to say that this or that is % ruled out. “Not least because I just don’t know whether at some time in the future – next year, the year after, the year after that – there might be a vaccine escape iant that doesn’t work with the current suite of vaccines.” Comment MORE ON NHSPlan BSchoolsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: baby urgently needs kidney transplant
story: Baby urgently needs kidney transplant to save le as mum desperately appeals for donorRoman Cook, aged just  months, was born with just one kidney prematurely at Scunthorpe General Hospital and his mum says he needs to get his kidney replaced or he may not live much longerRoman Cook is  months old and is in desperate need of a kidney transplant Image: MEN MEDIAByChristian BrayfordAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA baby is in urgent need of finding a kidney donor in order to save his le.Roman Cook, aged just  months, was born prematurely at Scunthorpe General Hospital at  weeks, with just one kidney. His family are not a match and are now looking for a living donor before time runs out. Mum Rhiannon told GrimsbyLive : I was told by the doctors that he was born with only one kidney which was ing at just three to five per cent its normal .Without the transplant, he could die. I understand itaposs a major operation for someone to undertake. But Iaposm a mother who is scared of losing her son. Iaposm worried I will lose my baby boy. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter When little Roman was just a few weeks old he was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease , which is a long-term incurable condition where the kidneys do not work as well as they should. It gradually gets worse over time and eventually, the kidneys may stop working altogether. Roman is being kept alive through a dialysis machine that keeps his kidney ing. The toddler has been on PD dialysis since last November and has to be on the machine for eight hours a night.  Romanaposs only kidney is working on limited capacity and he urgently needs a kidney transplant. If his condition is untreated for much longer, the consequences could be fatal. Rhiannon said: The things you would be wary of with a normal child are even worse with a child-like Roman. He canapost crawl because of his catheter, he canapost walk because the dialysis makes him tired which means he sleeps a lot.If you are on the kidney transplant waiting list the best treatment option for you is to receive a kidney transplant from a living donor. If you have a friend or relative who would like to be considered as a potential donor for you please ask them to contact the transplant team below. You are unable to telephone on their behalf.Being a living kidney donorIf you wish to be considered as a living kidney donor please contact the Transplant Co-ordinators below at the centre which your friend or relative is registered. Please speak to your friend or relative before you register your interest as a living kidney donor.Once you have contacted the live donor team, the next stage of the assessment process is for you to complete anda donor health questionnaire. Here is a link to the questionnaire which can be accessed either from a PC desktop or a mobile tablet device. PLEASE NOTE: in order to complete the questionnaire electronically you will need to download and save it.Rhiannon asks that you ask place Roman Cookaposs name in recipient details. and his date of birth, which is   .Then a Leeds Living Donor Transplant Co-ordinator will deal with the initial enquiry from there on.Alternatively, Rhiannon has asked that you email Leedskidneyappeal@nhs.net  use aposROMAN COOKapos as the email reference. You will then receive an email with a questionnaire to fill out. Then, there is a section for you to say that you wish to donate to a specic recipient. Please insert ROMAN COOK as the recipient.Alternatively you can print off and post to our address :Bradford Transplant Co-ordinators - Tel.  Hull Living Donor Transplant Co-ordinator - Tel.  Leeds Living Donor Transplant Co-ordinators - Tel.  York Transplant Co-ordinators - Tel.   He goes to Leeds Teaching Hospital for regular checkups Heaposs just the most wonderful human being and you wouldnapost be able to notice that he has a condition from looking at him. Heaposs always happy and smiley and makes you happy. But the pain and dficulty he faces is something he overcomes daily. Weaposre just really desperate to find my son a donor who can help transform his le because heaposs a happy, little boy who needs the help and care of someone to come forward and help him in his time of need. Roman is blood group type aposOapos and because of this, he will require a kidney from someone with the same blood group. Rhiannon said: Leeds Teaching Hospital will only consider undertaking the operationthe donor is healthy, below  years old as Roman is so young. The chances of finding the right donor are limited and we as a family are at breaking point to find the match. Roman is almost at the finishing line with all the tests and scans he has had to find the right donor, but weaposre just waiting for that one miracle that will make our dreams come true. Itaposs a le or death situation because Roman canapost live on dialysis forever. Weaposre desperate for a living donor because the success rates are much higher than those from a donor who is deceased. It can take weeks for the kidney to kick into action from a deceased person and it will likely lead to him needing more transplants in the future. The average waiting list for a deceased kidney donor transplant is two to three years. This has been made much worse by Covid- as there has been a lack of donors come forward because of restrictions. Iaposm not sureRoman has two to three years to be honest and that is why we are putting out this appeal to save my sonaposs le. news uk-news covid-plan-b-doesnt-go-"Coronavirus new cases and deaths on October ByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorDave BurkeNews reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe governmentaposs Plan B to deal with surging Covid cases over the winter does not go far enough - with more measures needed to prevent an NHS catastrophe, experts warn. Ministers are already facing pressure to implement Plan B, which will see compulsory mask wearing re-introduced, with people encouraged to work from home and vaccine passports required at hospitality venues. But with the NHS already stretched ahead of what is expected to be a dficult winter, medics warn that steps such as closing nightclubs must also be considered. Today the head of an all-party Parliamentary group on coronavirus accused the government of ignoring spiralling cases, making increased regulations more likely. In the past seven days more than , people have tested positive for Covid, while , people were in hospital with the virus, the Department of Health said yesterday. The UK is recording more than five times the rate of infections than many other European countries, with  Covid deaths reported in just seven days. Dr Deepti Gurdasani, public health researcher at the Queen Mary University of London, said thousands of lives could be saved in coming weeks - but the governmentaposs plan does not go far enough.  Dr Gurdasani told The Mirror that compulsory isolation for schoolchildren who have been exposed to Covid and the closure of poorly-ventilated venues like nightclubs over the winter must be considered. She said that at the current rate a further , lives could be lost to Covid in the two months to Christmas. Dr Gurdasani said: We need to remember that the NHS is in crisis, healthcare doctors will tell you that. Thereaposs very little leeway, emergency response times are high pretty much all across England. Right now people canapost get emergency care, which means avoidable deaths. Most people donapost realise that weaposre an exception to the rest of the world who arenapost tolerating this level of deaths. She described lockdowns as a failure of pandemic policy, and said measures such as closing nightclubs and isolation for schoolchildren who come into contact with Covid cases must be considered. Professor Deenan Pillay, who chairs the Independent Sage group, agreed that parts of Plan B will need to be strengthened, while MP Layla Moran, who chairs the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Coronavirus said nothing should be off the table.  During the second wave at the end of last year, parts of England were plunged into heightened restrictions, while a national lockdown was announced at the end of December as daily cases soared to more than ,. With the rollout of vaccines the number of fatalities has dropped dramatically. In January more than , deaths were announced for  consecutive days as the governmentaposs failure to respond to the Kent iant had tragic consequences. Daily death tolls are currently considerably lower, with yesterdayaposs figure of  the highest since July. Ms Moran, Lib Dem, told The Mirror: “As we see case numbers and deaths continuing to rise, it is clear that our NHS has once more been left on the brink of a Covid crisis.  “By continuing to ignore the importance of staying on top of case numbers, the Government is making mitigation measures such as mask wearing and ato home working increasingly likely. “When it comes to saving lives and protecting the NHS, however, nothing should be off the table and given the numbers of cases we are seeing, the Government is in no position to rule anything out.” Dr Gurdasani said that mask wearing - a key component in the governmentaposs Plan B - will help, but other steps will also be necessary. This means that the government may have to once again close crowded poorly-ventilated venues such as nightclubs, she said.Acting early and bringing in more measures will prevent Boris Johnson and co having to consider a lockdown, she said.She continued: Nightclubs are problematic, they are exactly the environment that Covid needs. Weaposve seen that large events can lead to thousands of infections, you just canapost keep people safe.  Lockdowns are presented as a main measure, but in reality itaposs a failure of early measures. Early action is what prevents lockdown. Driving up vaccination rates among young people and bringing in measures to improve ventilation in schools and workplaces are among the steps that need to be taken, Dr Gurdasani said. Professor Deenan Pillay, chairman of Independent Sage, agreed that Plan B does not go far enough. Thereaposs a lot in Plan B that can be useful, but there needs to be a strengthening in certain areas, he said. He said that CO monitors and airflow change devices should have already been rolled out in workplaces and schools - and said improving ventilation in these places must be a priority. I fully agree that schools should be open, but theyhavenapost wanted to deal with the work needed to make sure that schools are safe. Prof Pillay told The Mirror that there had been a suggestion that ensuring secondary school children have at least one dose of a Covid vaccine should be a priority.  I think that needs re-looking at, he said. He said he is in favour of vaccine passports, as they would reduce the risk of infections spreading in crowded places such as pubs and restaurants, and would incentivise people getting jabbed. Prof Pillay said it would be wrong to rule out a further lockdown, but said stronger measures can prevent the need for one. All think all things should be on the table, he stated.Itaposs always an option, we know that they did reduce infections, but I would say that comes at a cost, particularly for children. We should do everything in our power to keep schools open, but that means we should reduce as much as possible the risk of infections spreading. The government has said it will implement Plan Bit becomes clear the NHS is at risk of being overwhelmed. NHS Confederation boss Matthew Taylor, which represents the healthcare systems in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, said the new curbs were needed or the UK would risk stumbling into a winter crisis. But Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng ruled out imposing another lockdown - and even told Brits to go ahead with planning Christmas parties. story: Dad told he had nothing to worry about by doctors given dreaded cancer diagnosisMichael Moriarty said he initially went to the doctor about the issues around eight years ago, when he noticed blood whilst emptying his bowels, but was told he was suffering from haemorrhoidsMichael Moriarty lives with his partner Lyndsey and their two daughters, seven-year-old Libby and five-year-old Phoebe Image: Liverpool ECHOByLee Grimsditch:,  Oct | comments A dad whose pain was dismissed by doctors first as haemorrhoids then as Irritable Bowel Syndrome, has been given a heartbreaking cancer diagnosis.Michael Moriarty, , lives with his partner Lyndsey and their two daughters, seven-year-old Libby and five-year-old Phoebe, in Walton. The cleaner said he initially went to the doctor about the issues around eight years ago, when he noticed blood whilst emptying his bowels. The doctor dismissed his concerns as nothing more than haemorrhoids, a diagnosis he accepted over the next few years as the bleeding continued. However, in March , the dad of two headed to the AE after struggling with pain while working night shts. Doctors at the emergency room gave him a scan, from which they determined that he was “just very constipated”. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletterI was coming home and doing yoga and gave myself colonic irrigation off a kit bought from Amazon. I was trying everything but I was still in a lot of pain,” he told the Liverpool Echo.Weeks went by and Michael went back to the doctor and was now told it was likely he was suffering from Irritable Bowel Syndrome . Still in pain months later and dissatisfied with the diagnosis, Michael took himself again to AE and was given a CT scan. When a lump was found in his bowel, further scans and tests were booked. Following these, he was asked to come into the hospital to speak with a doctor. It was on Christmas Eve that he received the devastating news he was dreading. Michael was diagnosed with a cancerous tumour in his bowel as well as in his liver and lung. When she told me I broke down,” Michael said. “I mean, Iaposve got two young kids. It was a lot to take in. In January this year, he underwent an intensive course of chemotherapy, which succeeded in shrinking the tumours in his liver and lung. However, the bowel tumour remained the same. Michael subsequently underwent a gruelling bout of radiotherapy in an attempt to try and reduce the size of the tumour. Despite feeling positive that the treatment was working and that surgery could now be an option, he was dealt another devastating blow upon learning that the tumour in his liver and lung had gotten bigger. Next week, he is due to start another course of chemotherapy which doctors have said has a % chance of working. Michael is also fundraising to try and raise enough money for a tailored treatment only available in Germany. During his terrible ordeal, Michael said the support he has had off his family has been incredible. Lyndsey has been amazing,” he said. Weaposve got two young kids together and sheaposs been picking up a lot of the slack because I canapost do anything really. I donapost let the kids see how ill I am. My daughter even said, aposDad itaposs weird, you donapost even act sickapos. Hopefully, please god, this chemotherapy can work,” he added. Once I got the diagnosis everything has been quick but until you get to that point itaposs hard. They said because I was young it was IBS and nothing to worry about. And when I was told I had piles as a young man - I was only about  - it was just embarrassing really. Following his tough experience, Michael was urging everyone to “go and get checked”. “If you feel assomethingaposs wrong just go,” he said. You know your own body better than anyone andyou feel assomethingaposs wrong just keep going. title: its both exciting soothing wild
story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until November .Download the app, head in store or order online. title: know women being spiked needles
story: All we know about women being spiked with needles in UK nightclubs as MPs demand actionHome Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being spiked with needles at nightclubs across the countryZara Owen believes she was spiked with an injectionByWilliam JanesDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct  Dozens of young women have come forward to recall their terror in finding a prick in their arm or leg realising they had been spiked by injection in nightclubs.Several said they were avoiding clubs and house parties as a result - or were wearing thick denim to protect themselves. Police chiefs said plain clothes officers were likely to be deployed in nightclubs although womensapos groups warned some women struggled to trust forces in the wake of Sarah Everardaposs murderer.Home Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being injected at nightclubs across the country.Universities have said they are working with bars and police to help ensure studentsapos safety after the reports.Have you been affected by this story  Get in touch at webnews@mirror Campaigners call for changes to make night venues safer Groups from more than  universities around the UK have joined an online campaign calling for the boycott of nightclubs. Campaigners say they are seeking tangible changes to make night-time venues safer, such as covers stoppers for drinks, better training for staff and more rigorous searches of clubbers. A petition to make it a legal requirement for nightclubs to thoroughly search guests on entry, started last week, has already gained more than , signatures. The National Union of Students issue statement Larissa Kennedy, president of the National Union of Students , said: Itaposs absolutely disgusting that in the past few days a number of students have reported instances of women being spiked on nights out. My rage, love and solidarity goes out to all those who have been impacted by these violent acts, and all other women and marginalised folks who experience sexual violence on our campuses and in our communities. One studentaposs story A student has told how she believes she was spiked with an injection during a night out with friends as police say reports of spiking are on the rise.Zara Owen, , from Surrey, who is a student at the University of Nottingham, said she went for a night out with friends last Monday but then blacked out soon after arriving at a venue.Speaking to BBC Breakfast, she said: I went out with my friends to a nightclub in the city - nothing more than what we would usually do. I remember going to the bar, going to the toilet, going to the photobooth, and then after that moment my memory is a blank until I get home and Iaposm getting my phone charger. I know I didnapost drink as much as I usually would on a night out this night, and the fact that I donapost remember anything is terrying for me because this is something that is a very rare occasion to me.  Iaposve never suffered with memory loss and then the next morning, obviously I did with the memory loss, I woke up with a really painful leg. I found a pin prick in my leg which was the epicentre of all pain. It made me unable to walk and I was limping around. As a young person whoaposs at university, Iaposm hearing stories of people who have been to nightclubs and they have been injected. I have heard stories of someone having it through their hand or through their back so this kind of gave me an idea this had happened to me. Ms Owen added she was afraid that she may have contracted a diseasea dirty needle had been used. What did the university say  A University of Nottingham spokesperson said: We are extremely concerned by these reports - no-one should feel unsafe on a night out. We are working closely with Nottinghamshire Police and the cityaposs nightle venues to monitor, review and learn from incidents and experiences in the city centre. We have contacted them about the specic concerns raised and will continue to liaise with them to actively tackle societal problems and challenge behaviours.The NHS website provides some guidelines on what to doyour skin has been punctured with a used needle. They advise to aposwash the wound using running water and plenty of soapapos, aposdry the wound and cover it with a waterproof plaster or dressingapos and to not scrub the wound or suck any blood. Nottingham Policeaposs websites has some guidance on what to doyour drink has been spiked, but they currently do not have any guidelines on being injected. They advise to: Tell the people you’re with and make sure you’re someone where you feel safe. Alert a member of staff at the pub or club you are at. If you feel unwell you should seek medical attention immediately and tell them that you believe your drink has been spiked.Police in Nottinghamshire investigateNottinghamshire Police has seen a rising number of reports of spiking over recent months and are now stepping up operations to tackle the problem. Superintendent Kathryn Craner said: Over the last few months we have seen an increase in reports where people believe that drugs may have been put in their drink - thataposs due to the fact that they have experienced a distinctly dferent feeling to their normal reaction to alcohol. But weaposve also received a small number of reports where people are telling us, as Zara has, that this has been associated with a pain or a mark on a part of their body, scratching sensation, and as though they have been physically spiked. The force has arrested a man as part of the wider operation to tackle spiking in Nottingham. Police Scotland also investigate reports Police are investigating reports of people being spiked by injection in the Edinburgh, Dundee, Glasgow and Aberdeen areas. It follows reports on social media about people being targeted inside venues in Scotland. Police Scotland said a small number of reports from the four areas are being investigated but do not appear to be linked. The force has also received a report of a drink-spiking incident at a venue in the Stirling area and inquiries are ongoing. A Police Scotland spokesman said: We are aware of posts circulating on social media about spiking incidents involving injections in Scotland. Officers are carrying out inquiries, and a small number of reports from the Edinburgh, Dundee, Glasgow and Aberdeen areas are being investigated. These do not appear to be linked. We take all reports seriously and we would encourage anyone who believes they have been a victim of spiking in any form to contact police via .  What politicians are saying about the issue“ These are obviously vile crimes,” said Commons Home Affairs Select Committee chairwoman Yvette Cooper.Ms Cooper, a former Shadow Home Secretary, said she received a report today from a victim who attended a hospital casualty unit last night “as a result of a possible injection spiking”. The victim “referred to there being three other people who were in the AE at the same time for spiking more widely, who were unable to walk as a result of drink spiking”.Home Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being injected at nightclubs across the country.A Home Office source said: Weaposve asked the police to look into whataposs going on. We need to understand the scale of the problem. The thought of whataposs going on is just horrendous. What are the experts saying about it Some experts have cast doubt the use of needle spiking being a widespread phenomenon due to multiple iables such as the size of needle needed, the amount of liquid to cause an effect as well as the medical know-how needed to perform the injection.Guy Jones, senior scientist at drugs charity the Loop, told VICE World News: “GHB would be a poor candidate for injection due to the large amount of fluid needed, and therefore the thick, painful needle. This means that the substance involved would be something that would be highly detectable for several days in a toxicology screening such as a benzodiazepine.”David Caldicott, an emergency medicine consultant and founder of drug testing project WEDINOS, also said: “There are a couple of things that are disconcerting about this story. The technical and medical knowledge required to perform this would make this deeply improbable. It is at the level of a state-sponsored actor incapacitating a dissident, like the Novichok incident. The idea that a clubber would do this to a fellow clubber seems highly unlikely to me. title: most broken shelter dog finally
story: Most broken shelter dog finally accepts treat from volunteers after  daysBetty the shelter dog finally decided she was brave enough to approach a handler offering a treat on the st day of her stay at DogsRescue in WorsleyThe dog finally accepted a tasty treat after  days Image: DogsRescueByFiona Callow:,  Oct | comments A dog described as the most broken a shelter has ever seen finally took a treat from a volunteer’s hand for the first time in  days. Betty finally decided she was brave enough to approach a handler offering a tasty treat on the st day of her stay at DogsRescue in Worsley. Bettyaposs transformation was slow but incredible, and the sweet moment was captured on video, the Manchester Evening News reports.The shelter wrote in a video caption: “Betty taking a treat from our hands. This moment has been  days in the making. “Probably the most broken rehab dog we have taken, her transformation whilst slow is incredible.  Moments like this are golden. We are so proud of you Betty.” Later that day they shared the full video, and said: “Betty taking a treat. She’s sat and watched other dogs do this thousands of times. Love, kindness, time and patience pay off in the end. “This was on her st day at our rescue. All in your own time, beautul girl. There’s no clock ticking on how long you can stay here.” In the video, the handler stays calm and still, offering out the treat while Betty is seen looking around tentatively, starting to approach several times, before doubling back, taking a few steps backwards, and then starting again. She then seemingly surveys the area to make sure that the coast is clear before walking up steadily towards the handler, finally taking the treat very gently before beating a hasty retreat. The tweet has gained more than , likes and nearly  comments, with users praising the rescue for allowing Betty to overcome her fears at her own pace. DogsRescue was founded by Emma in  with the aim to rehabilitate dogs across Europe and the UK to homes in the Manchester area. They pride themselves on being a kennel free environment, and believe in ‘pack rehabilitation’, allowing the dogs to enjoy a lestyle where they can exercise and socialise with the other animals, gaining confidence from each other, before eventually being rehomed.  One user said: “That is so beautul to see but I can’t help thinking what the beautul baby has been through to be so frightened. “Thank you so much for your patience and perseverance. You guys are truly amazing.” Another commented: “Bless her, so thankful to you for giving her the opportunity to express herself at her own pace without the time pressure of finding a home. “Thank you for the wonderful work you do.” A third said: “Breaks my heart to see her check her escape route first. Thank goodness she has you guys.”In a further post on Twitter, the rescue said: “Betty is a smart, sweet dog who was unbelievably afraid. It was unthinkable to us to end the le of a healthy dog just because they need time and patience.“It’s a privilege to be on this confidence building journey with her and watch her blossom into a happy member of our pack.” Comment MORE ON FitnessAnimalsDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news new-covid-delta-plus-iant-"Coronavirus new cases and deaths on October ByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments The new strain of the Delta Covid iant could be even more transmissible, experts have warned.The so-called Delta Plus, also known as AY. will not effect current plans to tackle the spread of Covid during winter, despite fears the NHS could be overwhelmed by hospital submissions due to respiratory illnesses. Previous iants of the coronavirus have wreaked havoc as they can spike infection rates across the country.Health experts from the NHS are now encouraging the government to enact its contingency plan for further restrictions, which may include another lockdown. Business secretary Kwasi Kwateng said in response: This time last year we didnapost have the vaccine. We donapost want to go back into lockdown and further restrictions. A spokesperson for Prime Minister Boris Johnson added: As you know it’s something we’re keeping a very close eye on because of the strength of our genomic capability we are able to keep a very close watch on any iants that are emerging.What is the new Delta plus Covid iant  The new coronavirus iant, known as AY.., is an offshoot of the Delta strain, which is dominant across the world.Viruses mutate and change to fight against the antibodies that learn to kill them. It means immunity to viruses are often hard to keep up with. Some virus iants are more easily spread and can be more infectious. Some strains are also known to be more severe. Is the New Delta strain more transmissible  It is currently unclearthe new iant is indeed more severe or infectious. Tests are currently underway in an attempt to determine this. However, according to Dr Jeffrey Barrett, the director of the Covid- Genomics Initiative at the Wellcome Sanger Institute in Cambridge, and Prof Francois Balloux, the director of the University College London Genetics Institute, AY.. could be -% more transmissible than the original iant. He told the Financial Times: Its potential higher transmissibility could at this stage only explain a tiny fraction of additional cases. “It’s around % frequency [now], and assuming it may be % more transmissible, that would only explain an additional % extra infections [every five or so days].  However, the PMaposs spokesperson said: Thereaposs no evidence to suggest this iant, which I think is the AY. you are referring to, is more easily spread. There’s no evidence for that but as you would expect we’re monitoring it closely and won’t hesitate to take actionnecessary.” Thereaposs no evidence provided to us that we have seen that suggests it is more easily spread. Will the Covid vaccine still work  Experts say at this early stage, it is unlikely the new iant will escape the current vaccines. Tests are currently under way to establish how big of a threat this new iant poses. The Covid- Genomics UK Consortium , which tracks new iants, said the new iant “is likely to become dominant” in Britainit is found to be more infectious. However, it said there is no evidence to support this yet. More recently experts have argued there is a case for a Delta-specic vaccine, according to The Independent. story: Pub landlord left frustrated after group refuses to pay for meal after eating itThe Pack Horse, in the Peak District village of Hayfield, was visited by a group who left without paying despite staff checking on them when they first got their foodThe Pack Horse, which is in the Peak District village of Hayfield, is one of the North Wests leading and most respected gastropubsByDaisy JacksonAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA pub landlord has shamed a group of customers for refusing to pay for a meal they had already eaten. The Pack Horse, which is in the Peak District village of Hayfield, was visited by a group who didnapost complain when staff came and checked on them after they got their food. Staff say that the group chose to complain once theyaposd eaten most of the meal.The group allegedly tried to ask for a new dish, which was refused, and eventually left without paying the bill, Manchester Evening News reports. Owner and chef Luke Payne said that one member of the group then had the nerve to wink at him as they left. Were the diners right to leave  Have your say in the comments  The pub takes card details at the time of booking in case of no-shows or walk-outs, but the group reportedly said they would cancel their cards. Luke said the ordeal was immensely frustrating for him and his staff. He said: They were perfectly pleasant to begin with and then everything just changed. After theyaposd eaten about  per cent of the food, a lady brought her plate up to the bar and said it wasnapost to her liking, wasnapost what she expected, and could she swap to another meal for free   To which I said aposNoapos, because sheaposd eaten most of it and we canapost give food away for free when itaposs just personal preference. Thataposs not really how it works. Luke said his small team had already checked in with the group of customers and there were no complaints made about their food. When the group threatened to not pay their bill, Luke said he told them: aposThataposs not really acceptable, youaposve eaten most it, and you were given the opportunity to say there was something wrong with it.apos  He added: If theyaposd flagged it up in the check-back we could have done something to recty it. We donapost actively like making people unhappy, itaposs our job for people to have a really good night. We love people leaving with a buzz and knowing theyaposve had a great time with us, and  per cent of the people we have in are absolutely lovely and have a great time. We put in so much effort and passion and love, so every negative comment is taken personally. We will always do our utmost to fix a problemsomething is wrong -weaposve made a mistake weaposll hold our hands up and weaposll own it. So in an instance where absolutely nothing is wrong and people have kicked off, it hurts. The Pack Horse is one of the North Westaposs leading and most respected gastropubs, earning itself a place in the Estrella Dam Gastropubs list. Luke says that business has been great since they were able to reopen their doors after lockdown, but he says the post-pandemic kindness is fading. He said: I feel like there was a point in the pandemic where everyone was like aposBe kind, be nice. But Iaposve certainly noticed over the last couple of weeks that thereaposs been more stressed-out people with shorter tempers, and I know that thereaposs a lot of hard times for people at the moment, but it doesnapost take much to be nice to others. It was such a great opportunity to have that societal reset but I think some people have slipped back into their old ways. title: pub responds customer complaint after
story: Pub responds to customer complaint after they tried to eat Tesco meal deal on premisesThe man, known only as Owen, left the review minutes after leaving North Star in Cardf’s North Road in a huff on Tuesday afternoon - saying he was told off over the meal dealThe man, known only as Owen, left the review minutes after leaving North Star in Cardf’s North Road in a huff Image: MEDIA WALESByJonathon Hill:,  Oct | commentsA pub has responded to a customer review complaining about being asked not to eat a Tesco meal deal on the premises. The man, known only as Owen, left the review minutes after leaving North Star in Cardf’s North Road in a huff on Tuesday afternoon. “Told off for having a sip of a shop-bought Coke from the shop alongside my overpriced pint so left, attitude problem,” wrote the enraged Owen.North Star’s manager David Rowlands then shared the scathing review on the business’s page, reports Wales Online. After viewing CCTV footage of the man, David wrote: “Dear Owen, you were politely asked to not consume your Tesco meal deal in a pub when the kitchen is open, as is standard practice in any food or drink establishment, and the price of our Blue Moon on draught is probably one of the lowest prices in the whole city.  “We have CCTV footage of our manager asking you politely to not consume outside food and drink in our venue.” David later said: “He came in with a bag, bought a pint, and then started consuming his meal deal. First the crisps, then the sandwich, then the bottle of Coke. One of our staff went over to him and told him he wasn’t allowed to consume food and drink from where on the site on our food-serving days. “On a Sunday evening and on a Monday, when we don’t serve food, we do allow customers to get a Subway or order food inthey want. It’s no problem for us and I don’t want them to go hungry. I don’t think many places would do that.” It isn’t the first time people have brought their own food onto the premises, David said. Not long ago a group of men thought they’d try their luck by bringing a few pasties with them.  He explained: “We’re only just starting to get some profit since we opened last August. We’re only now starting to work at full capacity again. And so it is quite frustrating when people come in with their own stuff. It would be nicepeople could make an effort to eat at their local independent establishments. The pub is trying things to entice customers by giving % off for students on a Wednesday evening and live music at weekends as the hospitality industry recovers from the y closures inflicted by the pandemic. They’ll also soon be doing karaoke nights on Sundays. David added: “We work hard and like to look after our customers and we work hard to have that iety on offer so it’s a shame when people decide to bring a Tesco meal deal in instead.” Comment MORE ON TescoCCTVPubs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: queen showing slight cold signs
story: Queen showing slight cold signs but spotted driving Land Rover and walking dogsHer Majesty, , felt “a little tired” on Tuesday evening, before royal doctors were called to her living quarters at Windsor Castle, it is understoodHer Majesty, , felt “a little tired” on Tuesday evening, before royal doctors were called to her living quarters at Windsor Castle, it is understood Image: Getty ImagesByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Oct | comments The Queen has been ordered to put her health first after being forced to cancel a planned trip to Northern Ireland due to ill health. The -year-old monarch was feeling “a little tired” on Tuesday evening, before royal doctors were called to her living quarters at Windsor Castle, it is understood. Upon waking on Wednesday morning, ahead of a planned departure from her Berkshire home at midday to travel to Belfast, the steely Queen was said to be “showing slight signs of a seasonal cold”.Her Majesty, who has had a jam packed schedule of engagements since ing from her summer break at Balmoral, took covid test which confirmed she was not suffering from coronavirus. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up But palace medics advised her to take a period of “immediate rest” for the next few days. The nation’s longest reigning monarch is resting at Windsor Castle but will still receive her ministerial red boxes which she will attend to. She is still expected at this stage to host a reception in Glasgow on November  for the Cop climate change conference. Several engagements in her diary for next week remain as yet unchanged, but courtiers said they would maintain a “cautious view” with any plans. The Queen was set to attend a series of engagements at Hillsborough Castle on Wednesday and Thursday attend a service in St Patrick’s Church, Armagh to commemorate the centenary of the foundation of Northern Ireland. A Buckingham Palace spokesman said: “The Queen has reluctantly accepted medical advice to rest for the next few days.  “Her Majesty is in good spirits and is disappointed that she will no longer be able to visit Northern Ireland, where she had been due to undertake a series of engagements today and tomorrow. “The Queen sends her warmest good wishes to the people of Northern Ireland, and looks forward to visiting in the future.” It emerged this week that the Queen turned down the ‘Oldie of the Year’ trophy because she feels she does not meet the criteria, believing “you are only as old as you feel”. Despite her period of rest to take it easy, the Queen was spotted on Wednesday driving around the Windsor estate and enjoying taking her dogs for a walk. A royal source said: “The Queen’s enthusiasm for ing to a fully packed schedule of engagements following the coronavirus restrictions being lted has been incredibly admirable. “There is certainly no cause for alarm.  “Her Majesty doesn’t know any other pace than full on and used to being incredibly busy, especially of late, but perhaps it is in her best interests that she takes this time to rest and recuperate before she starts once again.” Courtiers believe the cancellation of the Queen’s trip will serve as a reminder that the head of state - at the age of  - cannot do what was expected of her  or  years ago. In recent weeks she has for the first time been seen walking with a stick at public engagements. Joe Little, managing editor of Majesty magazine, said the Queen’s autumn schedule had been more crammed than expected, but last-minute cancellations were inevitable in the future. Since the Queen ed from Balmoral Castle at the start of October, she has met Canadian troops at Windsor, launched the Queen’s Baton Relay for the Commonwealth Games, attended the Royal British Legion centenary service at Westminster Abbey, travelled to Cardf for the Welsh Senedd opening, and hosted a global investment summit reception, as well as holding audiences and video calls.  Mr Little said: “I think when you get to the age of  and you have a role such as the Queen has, there is an inevitability about last-minute cancellations. “Unfortunately, I think this is just how it’s going to have to be from time to time. “The fact that she has been busy and seemingly healthy and happy of late shows that clearly looks can be deceptive unless something has happened overnight.” He added: “Mentally, the Queen is pin sharp as ever and when she makes speeches she speaks well. “But you notice that the body is perhaps a little bit less so. “Every now and again there will be this reminder that she is  and she can’t do what was expected of her ,  years ago.  Just five years away from her th birthday and next year due to celebrate her Platinum Jubilee -  years on the throne, the nation’s longest reigning monarch still keeps a busy diary of events and audiences and deals with her daily red boxes of official papers. She held two audiences on Tuesday via video link from Windsor Castle, greeting the Japanese ambassador Hajime Hayashi and the EU ambassador Joao de Almeida, followed by a reception for business leaders including Microsoft founder Bill Gates in the evening. At the weekend, she enjoyed a day at the races at Ascot, and on Monday held a virtual audience with the new Governor-General of New Zealand. Royal sources said the Queen’s “enthusiasm to get on with the job” has shown now sign of letting up, but most conceded she would be advised to “take her foot off the gas” to maintain her health. It was revealed last week that Her Majesty had taken the “personal decision” to give up regular drinking by her doctors as she keeps up a busy schedule ahead of her Platinum Jubilee celebrations.  Due to her age the Queen is expected to have had her Covid booster jab, following her first inoculation in January.At the time she broke with protocol to announce she had been given her first injection, alongside husband Prince Philip, from a royal doctor at Windsor Castle.The head of state made the personal decision to let it be known she had accepted the vaccine to send a “message of hope” to the country, as Britain reaches a crisis point in the battle against coronavirus. story: Skeletal’ boy, , fed so much salt he couldnt put up fight’ during fatal attackArthur Labinjo-Hughes had more than six spoons worth of salt in his system at the time of his death in June last year, with Dr Roger Malcolmson stating it was more likely Arthur was repeatedly poisoned with salt contaminated food or fluidsArthur Labinjo-Hughes had more than six spoons worth of salt in his system Image: BPM MediaByCarl Jackson:,  Oct A aposskeletalapos six-year-old boy was allegedly fed so much salt he was unable put up a fight during a fatal assault, a doctor has claimed in court. Arthur Labinjo-Hughes had more than six spoons worth of salt in his system at the time of his death in June last year, a court heard. Consultant pathologist Dr Roger Malcolmson told a murder trial at Coventry Crown Court it was aposhighly unlikelyapos the boy poisoned himself. Thomas Hughes, aged , and his then-girlfriend Emma Tustin, , stand accused of killing his son Arthur at their home in Cranmore Road, Shirley. They both deny murder and multiple counts of child cruelty.  Giving evidence today - Tuesday, October  - Dr Malcolmson stated it was aposmore likelyapos Arthur was aposrepeatedly poisoned with salt contaminated food or fluidsapos in aposbrutal controlling circumstancesapos. He told the court it was less likely he was given a single portion of salt shortly before he collapsed at the Shirley home on June . Asked whether his raised sodium levels, combined with dehydration, would have contributed to Arthur being aposless physically able to resist a fatal assaultapos the expert witness said: Thataposs my suggestion, yes. If he had been suffering health side effects from being poisoned to the extent he is likely to have been in this case, then yes he may not have been able to put up much of a fight.  Dr Malcolmson had earlier told the jury that Arthur suffered apossevereapos eye injures, including a detached retina, aposvery rarely seenapos in child head trauma cases. The expert described them as apostowards the extreme endapos of the scale and put them down to apossevere blunt force traumaapos to Arthuraposs head. He said: At minimum, there has been a very signicant head impact, there may have also been a shaking-type mechanism.  Dr Malcolmson reiterated his belief that the cause of Arthuraposs death was a head injury which could not have been self inflicted because the boy would not have been able to generate enough force himself, the court heard. The court also heard that Arthuraposs left kidney was aposextremely smallapos while his thymus lymphoid organ in his chest appeared to have shrunk. Dr Malcolmson stated the latter was likely caused by apossevere and or prolonged physical stressapos and confirmed it could have been brought on by aposrepeated and sustained abuseapos.  It is alleged Tustin and Hughes aposisolated Arthur from the familyapos, aposassaulted himapos, aposdeprived him of water and made him stand in the hallway where he spent up to  hours a dayapos, the court was previously told. They both deny murder. Tustin has admitted one child cruelty offence but denies three others. Hughes denies all four counts. title: storm aurore batter parts england
story: Storm Aurore to batter parts of England and France with high winds and heavy rainStorm Aurore is a low pressure system set to bring high winds to the north of France and south of England on Wednesday and into early ThursdayThe south of England is expected to be hit with heavy rain and strong winds late on Wednesday and into Thursday Image: SOPA Images LightRocket via Getty ImagesByNeil Shaw:,  Oct | comments Parts of the country should be bracing for high winds and heavy rain as the week progresses, with a weather system called Storm Aurore moving through the English Channel.Storm Aurore is a low pressure system set to bring high winds to the north of France and south of England on Wednesday and early Thursday. Coastal areas are expected to be affected the most, Météo-France has warned. The French national meteorological service has named the storm, as more signicant impacts are expected there. The storm is expected to move through the English Channel late on Wednesday and into Thursday, bringing some severe weather for France, while some southern areas of the UK will see some lower-key impacts. The Channel Islands will see higher winds than the mainland UK overnight, Wales Online reported. The northern part of the frontal system wrapped around Storm Aurore glances into southern England as the system moves eastwards.Associated heavy rain has led to the Met Office to issue ayellow warning for rainthat covers southern England, from pm on Wednesday to am Thursday morning. However, the most impactful and widespread impacts associated with Aurore will be in its southern flank, which sits over northern France.The heavy rain in England could see between mm and mm fall in the warning area, with up to mm possible in some places. With this, will come coastal gales, with winds of up to mph possible in some exposed locations, and widely breezy where.  Met Office Chief Operational Meteorologist Dan Suri said the worst weather associated with the storm would be on its southern flank, over northern France. “The northern edge of Aurore will catch southern England, dealing us a glancing blow,” Suri said. “What this means for us is some heavy rain this evening and overnight. The Channel Islands, however, being closer to France, will be more directly in the firing line and experience high winds this evening and overnight. “Of course, high winds will also affect the English Channel so marine interests are encouraged to keep abreast of the shipping forecast.” Comment MORE ON Met OfficeWeather warningWeather" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Two men caught with almost £k of drug money in supermarket bags for le jailedPero Mitrovic, , was jailed on October  for  months and Milan Kosoric, , was sentenced to a total of four years and three months imprisonmentPero Mitrovic was jailed for  months Image: Kent Police   SWNS.COMByJulia RobertsChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsTwo men have been jailed after being found with almost £, of drug money stashed in supermarket bags for le. A court heard the plastic-wrapped bundles of notes were found in several shopping bags during a police raid at the home of Pero Mitrovic in Kensington, London, where he rented out a room to Milan Kosoric. Officers also found just over g of cocaine and drugs paraphernalia at the property and in a parked car outside. Prosecutor Tim Hunter told Maidstone Crown Court that the amount of cash found plainly doesnapost equate to the small quantity of the class A drug which had been ided into  deals. Both men, who have no previous convictions in the UK or their native country, admitted possessing criminal property in respect of the cash on a jointly owned basis.  Mitrovic, , was jailed on October  for  months and -year-old Kosoric, who also pleaded guilty to possessing cocaine with intent to supply, was sentenced to a total of four years and three monthsapos imprisonment. The flat in Redclfe Street was raided on March  this year and the cash totalling £, was found in Kosoricaposs rear bedroom. Mr Hunter said: The cash was bundled up and marked into separate amounts and kept in a iety of robust supermarket shopping aposbags for leapos. Police also found six bags containing the vast majority of drug deal bags, a sealing machine and money counter. A further  cocaine wraps were found in a VW car. Craig Rush, defending Kosoric, said he had been entrusted by those further up the chain to act as a storekeeper for the drugs and money. Tony Wyatt, defending Mitrovic, told the court he knew the money was related to crime but not that it came from drug trafficking.He added: He could and should have put a stop to what was happening and ask his co-defendant to leave the flat. However, Judge Charles Gratwicke said it beggared belief that on seeing the money and paraphernalia he would not have known what was going on. Passing sentence, he told Mitrovic: You clearly must have been aware of the criminal activity that was going on, you clearly were permitting that criminal activity to take place, and there is little doubt that there was to be some personal gain.  Jailing Kosoric, Judge Gratwicke added he had played an active role in the illicit operation. Class A drugs bring with them nothing but misery, degradation and occasionally death to those who become addicted, he said. Those who prey upon the addiction class A drugs bring can expect to receive immediate prison sentences to reflect societyaposs abhorrence of the evil trade and to deter others. Detective Superintendent Lee Morton of Kent Police who investigated the case, said: Kosoric and Mitrovic both occupied key roles in an organised criminal network, and whilst both of them may not have directly orchestrated the drug supply chains running into Kent, they had clearly been entrusted to look after and redistribute vast sums of criminal cash. Both men have now rightly been jailed and the fact that we have been able to successfully and permanently seize all the money is equally important. Some of the work we do can take months of painstaking investigation but it is important that people see that we wonapost allow criminals to benefit from their illegal activity. Any ill-gotten cash will be taken from them and where possible redistributed to our local communities for everyoneaposs benefit. story: Which type of cough is Covid  How to tell the dference between virus and a coldAs the worst cold ever sweeps the country, its natural for people to wondertheyre simply under the weather from a severe cold or been infected with Covid. Heres the full breakdown to help you tell the dferenceConcerns over Covid symptoms have risen as the worst cold ever sweeps the nation Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMalvika Padin:,  Oct | comments After nearly two years of Covid safety measures, such as staying at home, social distancing, sanitizing and wearing face coverings, many people are being struck down by whataposs been dubbed the worst lurgy ever.Having had limited exposure to ailments like colds over the last  months, our immune systems have become more susceptible to common colds, especially now that restrictions have lted. Soyouaposre suffering with a cold-like ailment and youaposre worried you have Covid, hereaposs everything you need to know - including symptoms and safety measures.What are the symptoms of a cold  Symptoms of the recent cold sweeping the UK appear to include :A sore or scratchy throat Losing your voice Body aches and continuous headaches Frequent sneezing A runny nose A continuous cough A change in smell or taste A fever or temperature from  degrees Celsius and above What is a Covid cough  According to a February  joint report from WHO-China, a dry cough is the second most common symptom of Covid-, with % people reporting it. A dry cough means youaposre coughing without phlegm, and in Covid sufferers, this cough is often very deep and low from the bottom of the lungs, according to medical experts. However, having a dry cough doesnapost necessarily mean you have Covid, as it can also be caused by allergies, being exposed to dry air, smoking and other health conditions like asthma and GERD.How can you tell the dference between a cold and Covid  The simple truth is you canapost really the dference based on the symptoms alone, because several symptoms are also experienced by those with Covid-. Experts have said that itaposs tough to tell the dference, especially for those who have taken two doses of the Covid jab.They have warned against self-diagnosis, recommending testing as the only sure way to know. If you have a continuous cough, fever or changes in sense of smell taste, the best thing to do is take a PCR or lateral flow test and stay at home until full recovery from symptoms, eventhe first few tests come back negative. Anyone suffering from respiratory symptoms is also advised to seek medical helptheir health worsens and symptoms such as shortness of breath, blue lips, chest pain, or coughing blood appear.How to reco ver q uic kly If multiple Covid tests have come back negative, it can be safe to assume youaposre suffering from a simple cold. The best way to recover from any common cold, no matter how severe, is drinking plenty of fluids, like hot water with honey and lemon for sore throats, using over-the-counter medication for aches and pains and resting as much possible. And though restrictions have lted, it is recommended that we ease back into socialising and partying until our immune systems are able to fend off these pesky colds.
